column1: #Text=The proposal from Dutch Minister of Justice Piet Hein Donner to strengthen the anti-blasphemy provisions of the criminal code has been rejected by a majority of the Tweede Kamer, the country's parliament.
#Text=Donner put forth the proposal shortly after the murder of Dutch filmmaker Theo van Gogh, but denied that Van Gogh's death had anything to do with the proposal.
#Text=NOS reported that Donner's own party, the Christian Democratic Appeal (CDA), supported his proposal.

#Text=However, their two coalition partners &mdash; the People's Party for Freedom and Democracy (Volkspartij voor Vrijheid en Democratie, VVD) and Democrats 66 (D66) &mdash; announced they would not back the ban.
#Text=The Labour Party, the largest opposition party, also refused to vote in favour.
#Text=Without their support, the motion could not be passed.
#Text=Consequently, NRC Handelsblad reports, Donner withdrew his proposal.
#Text=Although the Dutch criminal code already makes blasphemy illegal, the law has only been enforced three times since the 1930s.
#Text=The article in question states that anyone who ridicules a cleric or relic may be imprisoned for up to three months.
#Text=According to Dutch broadcaster RTL, Member of Parliament Lousewies van der Laan (D66), will make a motion on November 17 to have the article removed entirely from the criminal code.
